title: Is it correct, “It's been a year since I knew you”? - Quora

response.answer_text: This is almost correct! The correct way to say this is: It’s been a year since I met you. I think you are confusing the verb ‘to know’ with ‘to meet’. It is ‘since I met you’ because you are talking about that specific action at that time. You wouldn’t say ‘today I know Charles’, you would say ‘today I met Charles’. You would use the verb ‘to know’ if you wanted to talk about the whole length of the time: ‘I have known you for a year’. This takes every single day that they have know each other for into account. On the other hand, ‘It’s been a year since I met you’ focuses on that specific day that the two people met. I hope that makes sense.

Probably not. When you use “knew” it means something that you used to know but don't any longer. The sentence in its present form means I stopped knowing you a year ago. So it might be correct in the context of something that you might say to a close friend or lover that you have grown apart from during the last year. I think what you mean is something like: “I have known you for a year.” If you want a contrived sentence that has a similar form you can say “it has been a year since I first got to know you.”
